>>177988107
It is if you look into The Bicameral Mind.
tl;dr: our subconscious wasn't always an interior mechanism.
We/it literally used to project archetypal figures into our field of vision as warnings about things our still-active animal instincts were picking up but weren't making through to the higher functioning parts of our brains.

So if your semi-cut-off animal sense of smell picks up subtle warning signs of a poisoned water hole a "Demon" would appear and scare you off. Likewise if you detected a food resource or hidden, clear water. a "God" would appear and beckon you in the right direction.

Everyone who reports ghost experiences, reports them as solid and real. Just like the Beautiful Mind guy. Your subconscious is sending you an emergency signal on the big red phone on your desk, that NEVER rings, to gtfo. "This is a murder site", "Bad things happened in this hospital/insane asylum", "the electromagnetic spectrum here is fucky and will mess your wiring up", "This place is too stressful for you, go somewhere more peaceful".

Note: The Bicameral theory conflicts with mainstream "Yay, SCIENCE!" human evolutionary theory because it places the point of transition from animal-level to higher-functioning human intellect much more recently, and much more spread-out. Like, we had civilization while this mechanism was still active and we hadn't moved into the modern near-complete sublimation of what is now our subconscious mind.

the age old distincition is simplified as such:
>ghosts
are spirits of humans, or animals; whatever something that was once born, lived and then died and left a residual presence of some sort. Whether it's simply an afterimage or an actual surviving personality.

>demon
an inhuman spirit. Something that was never alive like in the above sense, almost always malevolent towards humanity.
I say almost always because back in the old days things weren't always so clear cut.
For example Pazuzu, the entity depicted in the Exorcist, is based off the Sumerian demon (the statue in the film) of the north wind, who yes was a malevolent monster responsible for plagues etc., but pregnant mothers would give offerings to it so that it would protect their children from the other demons who harm women who are pregnant or some thing like that.

>>177995983
I've seen nearly everything up to Casino Royale, I still haven't watched Moonraker or Man with the Golden gun. Spy flicks aren't my thing, they're all fairly forgettable to me, although for some the Brosnan movies stand out with the most memorable plots, but I only actually liked GoldenEye, the others were stupid and I wish I could forget the plots but for some reason my mind holds onto them the most. In fact thinking it about it right now, I probably recall those the most so I can remember to not concern myself with ever watching them again.

I like Sean and most of his movies are solid, but Never Say Never again is pretty meh and they recreate an exact scene from Thunderball, a pretty cool scene in both movies, but lazy.

Lazenby had one of the most interesting stories to work with, but he idk, serviceable but not memorable? Hard to describe.

Moore is fairly insufferable, but he had some of the better Bond Girls to play off of and the tech in his films gets ridiculous and the money they spend on his exploits really can keep you engaged but damned if I remember much of the plots, except for that moronic voodoo plot in Live and Let Die.

Dalton was sort of a middle ground between Sean and Roger and I'm sorry he did not get to make at least a 3rd film. I liked License to Kill, but the overall consensus seems to be it's inferior to the Living Daylights.

I like Brosnan the most, but besides Goldeneye the the plots are trash and the feel of those films are way more corny and cheesy then they should be.

Craig's movies are as dreary as you can't get with the Bond character. Very "grounded" but it sucks the fun right out of the franchise. Casino Royale has a torture scene where someone smashes James' testicles. I'd rather watch Brosnan's cheesy movies or Moore's pompous smugness than that shit.

Idk I feel like it's a "your mileage may vary" scenario.

Of the pre-Craig era, I have never really cared for Diamonds are Forever and consider A View to a Kill to be terrible; if we include Never Say Never Again then that film is just a waste of time more than anything. A lot of people (at least did, it seems to have become a discredited meme / opinion has changed on the matter with the Craig-era) say that Die Another Day is bad; personally, although I get why people may dislike it, DAD is okay/enjoyable although by no means do I think it is great. As a whole I dislike the Craig-era - Casino Royale is the best of that bunch however, it has problems when it comes to actually feeling like 'a Bond film' and some of the issues of the Craig-era originate within it. My personal favourite Bond film is probably The Spy Who Loved Me (or at the very least it encompasses the key elements that to me make good to great Bond film), and I also really like both of the Dalton outings.

RotJ to TPM was 16 years, not 20.
He lost his sense of storytelling. By 1999 he had nothing to prove. He already told his moral tale, he already created the worlds premier special effects studio, he already changed entertainment forever, he already showed the big studios he was right and they were wrong (very very wrong).
With unlimited time and resources, no constraints to overcome, no other illuminated people trying to make a dream nobody believes in come alive, a guarantee his new Star Wars films would make millions… he created something bland and out of step with his magnum opus.
The original trilogy was all the right ingredients, all the right people, all the right constraints at the exact right time. It will never happen again.

I think a big reason OT Star Wars guns were so unique was that they weren’t spacey. For lack of a better term, they kit bashed guns or gun parts and glued or welded on ridiculous scopes and crap and many had wood stocks or grips. That’s what made it so different than all other sci-fi which either used your typical ray gun or something “generically” futuristic.

Whoever was doing the prop work here knew that’s what the old guys did, except they didn’t do anything to the ak. I have no idea what the fuck they were thinking. It’s disgusting how little effort went into this. It’s not even half baked, it’s not baked at all.

It’s also far too recognizable of a gun to be used in Star Wars even if they dressed it up. Sterling SMGs and Mauser C-96’s weren’t exactly unknown, but they weren’t as massively recognizable and prolific as the ak.

>>177971609
Started campy and weird. Absolutely surreal development as the creative team stumbled from direction to direction. But the unique leverage and freedom they gave their supporting characters made it an intensely interesting show because you never knew what each member of the crew might be up to in a given period. They might outright rebel against John if they thought his plan was stupid, further complicating the plot of a given episode!
But then it steadily found its legs and just kept picking up speed with its quiet insinuations that gradually became loud proclamations; The tone shifting as the villains became more and more desperate to stop the Scarens...
and so the final season and Peacekeeper wars were better than they had any right to be. The series finale on the space station, beginning with John's Blue Light Special speech, is the example every adventurous sci-fi series should hold itself to.

>>177997966
Because when you're investing millions into a film/show, you want to hire people who are most likely give you return, you don't want to take risks. The most reliable predictor of that is that they've made things which were profitable in the past. That means people with established careers who are most likely guild members. A non guild member might write something great, but will they write something marketable? Something profitable?

That said it's not like nothing was made during that time; non-guild writers were hired, sometimes directors or even actors filled in writing roles, eg Quantum of Solace.

>>177997886
>Joker's life is infinitely shitter than Travis'.
Very superficial take. Travis is a fallen angel character, like Hamlet. It's not that his life is "shitty", it's that he becomes aware of all the evil and filth in the world and he doesn't know how to process it. In the end, he becomes an avenging angel set on punishing humanity for its crimes. It's an interior, subjective, psychological fall, a spiritual descent into the demonic. Taxi Driver has an ambience of the psychedelic avd the surreal.... So the fact Travis' life is "less shitty" is irrelevant. The question is which is the more convincing psychological portrait of the scandalised soul, the man who has given up on humanity and sacrificed his own? Taxi Driver is head and shoulders above Joker.

>>177996895
>>177997166 is right about Cain. They get as repetitive as the Ghosts novels, but they remain fun reads despite that. The Eisenhorn books are great, the Ravenor sequels are pretty good too but have a different feel, and the Bequin finale trilogy...might be going full-retard, so maybe give it a miss until the last one is out and you can read some reviews. You can see what I think of the Gaunt books above, I'll add that the Double Eagle spinoff novel about fighter pilots is also good and more in the spirit of the first half of the main series. If you still want more, the Shira Culpurnia books are pretty decent - Arbitrator solves crimes, uncovers mysteries, kicks ass, though they're a bit on the slow side -
and several of the old(and a couple of the new) Necromunda-set novels are pretty cool if the gritty, goth-punk pseudopostapocalypse gang wars angle appeals to you. I quite enjoyed the Ahriman series. The novel about Knights is ridiculous in all the right ways(Drop Keeps!).

Beyond that it's mostly an endless sea of marinewank/bolterporn, which I can't speak to as I don't read it.

I view the points made in these posts in parallel because the distressing thing about AI content isn't that it's good, it's that it isn't "the worst" compared to what we actually get from the fucking flesh and blood lately.

Like, the AI makes some dramatically lit pastiche of an '80s practical effects genre flick. It's not THAT impressive, except in the context of "every billion dollar studio in the world today fails to reach the quality level of an '80s practical effects genre flick"

And as for bot posts on social media? You'll be able to run a sort of Turing test when you read an opinion online that kinda makes sense, like it hits some keywords and articulates something approaching an idea, but is a bit awkward. You know that's from a bot, but if the post is just an absolute 70IQ keyboard chewing "XAXAXAXA <clearly absurdly false thing> IS TRUE, I FUCK YOUR MOTHER YOU MAD?!" Well, that post definitely 100% came from a human being. If you stretch the definition of "human being" to include Indians and South Americans.

I have never seen bots capable of being as stupid, as inane or as frustrating as people can be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>177988743
Not really. I'm sure a handful of people have done that, but it would make for a very bad viewing experience. Watching someone else play a game is generally boring as fuck unless you're talking to them while they do it (or they're a very entertaining streamer and you're more interested in their performance than in the game). And if you instead cut out all the gameplay, you ruin the pacing and remove most incidental dialogue, worldbuilding, and environmental storytelling.

Most "<game> full movie" videos try to split the difference by keeping a few fragments of gameplay here and there, but it's necessarily a hack job that butchers the intended story and experience.

>>177995546
>and wonder what the fuck is going to happen when his mom dies.
That's the question plaguing the minds of every parent of an autistic child.
The best one can do is bring them to a position where they can handle themselves to some degree, preemptively locate a good environment for that child like one of those whatchamacallit, these closed communities with carers, and hope for the best.
I'm worried for my sister because she's what I believe is called middle functioning, so she's worse off than the autistic people that are basically normal-but-weird and she's nowhere near the low functioning autists (which I think your brother is from your description), so finding an environment for her is tricky.
She spent her school days in a regular school at a small class and her teachers had a lot of problems with her because she'd cry for no immediately obvious reason and was moody (How the fuck is a special ed teacher unaware of what autism and puberty combined looks like?), so they strongly recommended a special needs school in my neighborhood.
By chance my school visited that school and it was horrible, girls in my class were crying seeing these kids literally drooling, having their arms in a claw shape and banging their heads.
She's in an infinitely better position than they are so that school would offer them nothing, and what's more low functioning autists kind of trigger her, and who can blame her?
Imagine you're you and have authority figures insist low functioning autists are your peers, it would be horrible.
Not only are they horrible to be around (not that they can help it) but it would make anyone go "am I really that bad?".

The spectrum of autism is really interesting, one time when she was at school she brought a friend over and they were playing mario kart Wii.
You couldn't tell something was off from exchanging a few words but then they'd play and if he was losing he'd just reset the Wii, even while playing my sister.
It was frustrating to watch.

It's really not rough on me at all, it's my parents who carry the burden, I'm rarely more than a frustrated spectator.
>Now I feel guilty for wanting to ask about your sister's puberty
Well, there were never any incidents involving indecency if that's what you're referring to, there were a few situation where she had a "boyfriend" from class (only girl in a class of like 9 people) but those would end up as a "date" after which they'd both forget they were doing a thing together.
In a way what we got instead is worse.
She'd talk about getting married and having kids a minimum of once a day, she doesn't talk about it as often today but her eyes still light up at the sight of little kids.
It's soul crushing.

In fact she had a really big falling out in this support group she's in over it.
My parents put her in this support group thing that hosts weekly meetings and helps with jobs and the like, and there's this one girl there who's a big success story, working a decent job and adjusting well.
So naturally we hoped they'd be friends (especially since finding a girl peer to my sister is hard considering how boys are far more likely to be autistic), but then a certain incident happened.
During one of those weekly talks this girl brought up how she's okay with not having kids because she doesn't want them to begin with, and my sister really, REALLY didn't like hearing that.
They got into a pretty harsh argument supposedly and refuse to talk to one another ever since.
I would like to know why the staff member hosting this meeting didn't diffuse the situation or why he couldn't be replaced with a houseplant, but that ship has sailed, oh well.

>Will I still be able to follow along
Well, the story is not exactly complicated, but there's some humor in it akin to Dead Alive that requires you to understand what is being talked about once they reach the brothel, still, as far as the zombie splatter it won't matter.
The main plot is some biospill reaches a poor seaside community in the deep end of rural brazil, guy on a fishing trip get bitten by some mutated fish creature, he returns home, gets sick and starts infecting people during the opening party for a nearby brothel filled with big booby sluts, zombie mayhem insues etc.
There is also sideplot about a certain part of brazilian folklore which concerns a mythical grimoire containing dangerous spells https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Book_of_Saint_Cyprian

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When you start to think about it the human presence on Pandora is a lot of precarious than you'd expect considering their technology.
But in fact despite their initial push to properly colonize the planet they're on the end of an extremely complex and slow 6 year supply chain with their greatest limitation being manpower followed by resource extraction and refinement.
Each ISV has a 200 passenger limit and arrives every few months (6 in avatar 1, probably more frequent in avatar 2).
Automation seems to be common in the human city in avatar 2, but they still rely entirely on manned vehicles and manned resource extraction operations in remote isolated locations connected by helicopter or in the best case train or the whaling ship. This means engineers, scientists, miners, machine operators, medical doctors, corporate stooges and tons of other specialists that need to be on these spaceships every time as they rotate, however there's also crew for all the vehicles and most importantly soldiers to protect every installation from the dangerous wildlife and na'vi guerrillas.
And despite new humans arriving every few months they have been hired for a job 6 years beforehand and are supposed to do that when they arrive, so they can't be shifted to replace someone else without their original job being left undone.

In avatar 2 Jake and his na'vi destroy an armored train and its escort and then the response helicopters. The general woman then mentions that Jake is constantly leading attacks like that disrupting the supply lines and killing colonists that are practically irreplaceable. The humans basically are just looking on while they're being bled dry. Logically their city should be starved for resources.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
2/2
Sure they can put up a building in six days but not when the iron ore they need to make the steel rebar is in the cargo hold of a rusting train that was blown of the tracks 3 months ago and the pilot of the heavy lift helicopter the need to salvage is is nailed to his seat with a arrow in some helicopter wreck in the jungle.

How to solve this is likewise very difficult, send more troops? Great now you can't send the people you need to build your colony. Blast more of the moon with your engines? Extremely inefficient and they want to preserve as much as possible for human settlement. Send in a large force to flush out the na'vi guerrillas? They mention they tried that and it failed (making the manpower problems even worse). Quaritch's small team actually seems like a reasonable option even if it is desperate.

In fact the humans are extremely lucky most na'vi tolerate them and don't fight back, although antagonizing them like Quaritch did might change that

>>177990841
No not really. The whales aren't mentioned until at least halfway through the film, and just serve as fodder to advance the plot. The conflict is between Jake Sully (protag from the first one) and the gigachad head marine from the first one (they backed up his consciousness prior to a mission and grew him into a blue person). Gigachad is tasked with killing Sully for leading an insurrection, gigachad hunts sully and makes multiple threats on his children, and Sully decides to go into hiding to protect his children and take heat off of his clan. Gigachad finds out Sully's general location but can't locate him through intimidation of other blue people tribes, so he starts brutally killing whales (exactly two) and floating their bodies to bait the blue people. The humans and blue people had a detente over the whale killings prior to the movie and there was no conflict. The humans killed whales in deep ocean away from villages (the blue people have boners for the whales, naturally, and the whales come to play with the blue people in their lagoons regularly as part of their migration patterns) and sunk the bodies when they were done, and the blue people just let it slide. So gigachad kills a a mother and calf near a village and floats the body as bait. It's also explicitly mentioned that when they whale they take a mother and leave the calf, so it's weirdly, for Cameron, kind of a sustainable harvesting pattern, although, as you would expect, the whalers are depicted as pieces of shit.

Ahsoka was never EU. She was created by George Lucas. She is a part of the Lucas-verse.

>“I am the father of our Star Wars movie world - the filmed entertainment, the features and now the animated film and television series,” he says. “And I’m going to do a live-action television series. Those are all things I am very involved in: I set them up and I train the people and I go through them all. I’m the father; that’s my work. Then we have the licensing group, which does the games, toys and books, and all that other stuff. I call that the son - and the son does pretty much what he wants.” He laughs. “Once in a while, they ask a question like ‘Can we kill off Yoda?’, things like that, but it’s very loose. Then we have the third group, the holy ghost, which is the bloggers and fans. They have created their own world. I worry about the father’s world. The son and holy ghost can go their own way.”—George Lucas: Mr Emperor Strikes Back, Times Online, 2008

>George Lucas: "We've been doing [The Clone Wars] for three years. We have one year finished, we're in the middle of the second year. I've written the third year. We expect this to go on for at least five or six years."

>“This is Star Wars, and I don’t make a distinction between The Clone Wars series and the films.”—George Lucas, SciFiNow, October 2011

>Furthermore, there would be no cherry-picking the series; a network had to take all twenty-two episodes or lose out altogether. “It’s much easier for me to just do the show I want, [then] say, ‘Here it is, do you wish to license it or not?’” Lucas said with only a hint of exasperation. “That’s it. I'm the father, Howard Roffman [president of Lucas Licensing] is the son and the holy ghost is the fans, this kind of ethereal world of people coming up with all kinds of different ideas and histories. Now these three different pillars don't always match, but the movies and TV shows are all under my control and they are consistent within themselves. Howard tries to be consistent but sometimes he goes off on tangents and it's hard to hold him back. He once said to me that there are two Star Trek universes: there's the TV show and then there's all the spin-offs. He said that these were completely different and didn't have anything to do with each other. So I said, "OK, go ahead." In the early days I told them that they couldn't do anything about how Darth Vader was born, for obvious reasons, but otherwise I pretty much let them do whatever they wanted."

>Dave [Filoni]: This series at least to George is NOT EU, it is a part of Star Wars as he sees it. I think if anything there was a period where Henry [Gilroy] and I had to learn exactly what it took to be a part of George Lucas’ Star Wars, and tell the Star Wars story his way. We had to learn how to look at the Galaxy from his point of view and let go of some of what we considered canon after we found out the ideas were only EU. Really we had to “unlearn what we had learned” and go back to the movies as the defining source material.

Piggy in Lord of the Flies (B&W) was pretty nasty.
It's when the boys cross over the line from larping kids into primal, mindless savagery.

Most social media soiys who want le meme revolution don't realize that they'll die like Piggy on the first day when the real "mindlessness-rules" savagery starts. When even the leaders of the savage factions lose control of their lieutenants. The people who understand what's (really) involved in a big turning point like that will be forced to step back and let this phase pass, then move in to wipe out the savages to bring stability again. The "Piggys", the weak/dependent, will die in a raw, primal state of terror, confusion and betrayal.

Annoyingly, the only clips available have changed Piggy's shrill cry of terror at the moment of his death. And it now sounds more like a kid playing at soldiers dying ("Raargh!").

This one gives the best context and cuts out the revised cry in favor of some dialogue overlay:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0PUudc2Qey8
Even the Conch giving him a sense of false security and authority is extremely reminiscent of modern social media softboys talking about BIG IMPORTANT THINGS, while inviting their own doom.

Tellingly, Piggy is presented as almost completely blind without his glasses.
He doesn't see his death coming til it's right on top of him.

Fun fact:
Piggy was played by a young Ronald Lacey who later played Toht in Raiders of the Lost Ark, where he got the second most brutal death in cinema history.

>The children were hired after Peter Wei-Teh Chen, Renee's uncle, was approached by a colleague whose wife was a production secretary for the film. Chen later testified that he was never informed that either of the children would be in proximity to a helicopter or explosives.

>Le and Chen were being paid under the table to circumvent state law, which did not permit children to work at night. Landis opted not to seek a special waiver, either because he did not think that he would get permission for such a late hour or because he knew that he would not get approval to have young children in a scene with a large number of explosives. Casting agents were unaware that the children would be involved in the scene. Associate producer George Folsey Jr. told the children's parents not to tell any firefighters on the set that the children were part of the scene and hid them from a fire safety officer who also worked as a welfare worker. A fire safety officer was concerned that the blasts would cause a crash, but he did not tell Landis of his concerns.

Modern reactors can reuse about 80% of the spent fuel, and most of the stuff that can't be reused can be repurposed. The long term repository that they *finished* at Yucca and then got blocked from using by the Obama Administration is big enough to store a century's worth of high level waste, even if we doubled the number of plants in the US.

PV and wind turbine efficiency is asymptoting and fusion isn't ready yet, that leaves fission as the only viable medium-term energy solution unless we're prepared to accept the majority of the human population being downgraded to pre-industrial standards of living.

You do know most Earth-based probes and satellites have to be limited to anywhere from a few hundred watts to a few kW, right? And that deeper space missions are usually even further limited, right? They have to squeeze every fucking ounce of efficiency out of the design of spacecraft, which makes for piss poor resiliency and flexibility with mission parameters. The ISS has something like 3500 square meters of panels and it tops out at around 80-100 kW. The same panels in Mars orbit would top out at 40-50 kW, and at Jupiter they'd be down to just fucking 3-4 kW. Inverse-squared law is a fucking bitch.

You're not colonizing Mars or the outer solar system with fucking solar panels and windmills, you need nuclear. Preferably fusion, but fission at the least. And the more we fucking shy away from it because a bunch of hippy faggots bought into the propaganda that everything with the word nuclear in the name is bad, the harder it will be to improve on it.

well yes, the economic calculation problem is unsolvable. You can throw resources at a problem, but then you don't know if what you are doing is really working and if some other important need is not met
>>177969925
all good, but healthcare and welfare are not something that you can give everyone one time and be done with it. There are infinite ways to provide for healthcare and the welfare of the people.
Also you still don't know how much of what is needed at a certain moment in a certain place. This is why in countries like Canada, Italy, etc where there is free healthcare there may be incredibly long lists for relatively simple (but lifesaving) operations, while more complex operations can be done immediately.
Btw the US system is shit too, it also partly incur in the economic calculation problem, although it's mostly about artifically limiting supply (government decides how many doctors there can be, what is a doctor, what procedures are healthcare and allowed, etc etc). Also medicare and medicaid may be setting the prices indirectly, causing misallocations since they also incur in the economic calculation problem
>>177969914
the waste of resources is not meant as "helping the poor is a waste", in this case it means you actually don't provide for those in need because without economic calculation you can't know who is in need, what do they need, when do they need and how to procure what they need
>tl;dr: start with reading the basic economics book by this wise man and learn economics. Stop being retarded, stop supporting the wrong policies, stop being James Cameron and a traitor of the human species

Nigger if you don't understand the uses for superconductors that's on you. You don't get to be brain dead ignorant and pin it on the film. We use (shitty) superconductors today in fusion reactors, trains, medical imaging, and other niche uses. Go-to functional fusion reactor designs require superconductors, and keeping them at near zero in proximity to gigahot plasma is one of the challenges of fusion energy. The ships used in Avatar, which operate under known physics, would require superconductors in their engines. The film is written to cater to two audiences: people who have passed the eighth grade, know what superconductors are, and have some understanding of their importance, for which an explanation is given, and for retards that don't, for whom the title unobtanium is given, consoling their ignorance with "we know you were too busy jerking off in school, don't let us bore you with a middle school science lesson, this material is rare, valuable, and important, that's all you need to know."

When Salvador Dali discussed his creative process, he framed it as what he called "the paranoicritical method," which involved interrogating (deconstructing) the world with the assumption that everything in the world was about himself. Similar to this is the Discordian concept of the Law of Fives, which states that everything is connected, in some way, to the the number 5. Robert Anton Wilson, discussing the Law of Fives notes that it is always true that all things are connected to the number 5 given sufficient creativity on the interpretive powers of the interrogator.

Feminist critique has a problem. It appears to be nothing more than a game in which a person, such as yourself, takes an a thing, such as this trope, and then examines it in order to prove the fundamental principle of feminism, namely that All Men Are Bastards. I can attest to this as a former Park Ranger in Florida going to schools and talking to kids about how to stay safe in the parks and to never get too close to the water (because gators and crocs) etc. etc. and then answering all the kids' questions and then shaking hands with all the teachers, principals, AND the fucking parents...

Well, the first time I had to do it I literally HAD to stop smiling about 45 minutes in because I had never smiled for that long and my face muscles that control smiling just tapped out, so then I started doing them in small reps only when someone was looking until my face was literally shivering; it was definitely eerie, like I didn't know you could physically get tired of smiling and just have to give up. Brought it up to my gf at the time who was a hospice nurse and she told me that on my time off to just sit in front of a mirror and practice smiling, and to treat it like a workout. It's not admirable at all.

In the next act he shoots his best friend on the spot for falling in love with his sister. Does this sound like someone with a carefully constructed moral calculus who weighs the impact of his actions on others? Or is he just a low-functioning thug who gives himself the trappings of "morality"?

The latter could've been kicked to the curb and been told to tell Sosa he has his limits. Did he think in any other way to finish the hit that would have spared the family, but not the Senator? No, the only thing he does is work himself up into a rage and shoot Alberto in the head.

That's not admirable behaviour, nor is it the behaviour of a "morally grey" character who lives "by their own code". It was a pure, self-serving backlash. This is why the "good-guy mobster" meme is bullshit and is the literal definition of white-washing
